revision.text:
{{Infobox military conflict |conflict=Battle of Bantam |image= |caption= |partof=[[Dutch-Portuguese War]] |date=27 December 1601 |place=[[Bantam Bay]], [[Indonesia]]| |result=Dutch victory| |combatant1={{flag|Dutch Republic}} |combatant2={{flagicon|Portugal|1578}} [[Portuguese Empire]] |commander1=| |commander2=| |strength1=5 ships |strength2=8 galleons
several [[fusta]]s |casualties1=Unknown| |casualties2=3 [[fusta]]s captured |campaignbox={{Campaignbox Dutch-Portuguese War}} {{Dutch colonial campaigns}} {{Portuguese colonial campaigns}} }} The naval '''Battle of Bantam''' took place on 27 December 1601 in [[Bantam Bay]], [[Indonesia]], when an exploration fleet of 5 Dutch under the leadership of Walter Harmensz. and a fleet under Andrea Furtado de Mendoça, sent from Goa to the Portuguese authority to restore, met in the Indonesian archipelago. The Portuguese were forced to retreat.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bataviawerf.nl/hoe-en-waarom-voerde-de-voc-oorlog-in-indie.html|title=Hoe en waarom voerde de voc oorlog in Indie|website=Batavia Werf|date=|accessdate=23 November 2017|language=nl}} Netherlands made three ships booty on a large Portuguese force majeure of eight galleons and miscellaneous smaller vessels. ==Ships involved== * Netherlands ** Gelderland ** Zeelandia (Jan Cornelisz) ** Utrecht ** Wachter (yacht) ** [[Duyfken]] (yacht) * Portugal ([[André Furtado de Mendonça]]), 30 vessels total ** 8 galleons ** several fustas (similar to galleys) - 3 set alight and captured by Dutch == References == {{coord missing|Indonesia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Battle Of Bantam}} [[Category:Naval battles of the Dutch–Portuguese War|Bantam]] [[Category:1601 in Asia]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1601]] [[Category:Battles involving the Dutch Republic]] [[Category:Naval battles involving Portugal|Bantam]] [[Category:Battles and conflicts without fatalities]] [[Category:Dutch conquest of Indonesia]] [[Category:1601 in the Dutch Empire]] [[Category:1601 in the Portuguese Empire]] {{Portugal-battle-stub}} {{Netherlands-battle-stub}} {{Asia-hist-stub}}

{{Infobox musical artist | name = Chaartaar ensemble | image = Chaartaar.jpg | alt = | caption = Cover of '''Baaraan Toee''', released in 2014 | image_size = | background = group_or_band | alias = | origin = [[Iran]] | genre = [[Persian traditional music|Persian fusion music]] | years_active = 2011–present | label = | associated_acts = | website = | current_members = [[Arman Garshasbi]] (singer)
Arash Fathi (composer)
Ehsan Haeri (poet)
Aeen Ahmadifar (arrangement) | past_members = }} '''Chaartaar''' ({{lang-fa|چارتار}}) is a [[Persian classical music|Persian]] fusion band[https://itunes.apple.com/us/artist/chaartaar/id821133199 Chaartaar] founded in 2011. ==Members== * [[Arman Garshasbi]], vocalist * [[Arash Fathi]] * [[Ehsan Haeri]] * [[Aeen Ahmadifar]] ==Style== [[File:Chaartaar at Milad Tower nowruz 1395.jpeg|thumb|Chaartaar concert for [[Nowruz]] at Milad Tower, Tehran, 2015]] The group’s style is a fusion of [[electronic music]] combined with [[Avaz (Persian vocal music)|Persian vocal music]].[http://www.radiopadide.com/Artist/Chaartaar Chaartaar at radiopadide.com] In September and October 2016 "Chaartaar" had their first live tour out of Iran, they started their tour from [[Vancouver]] in [[Canada]] and continued it in [[Calgary]], [[Montreal]] and [[Toronto]]. After that they traveled to [[Europe]] and continue their tour in [[Rotterdam]], [[Düsseldorf]], [[London]], [[Manchester]], [[Gothenburg]], [[Stockholm]] and [[Frankfurt]].http://www.chaartaar.com/en/events/ ==Albums== {|class="wikitable" ! style="background:#B0C4DE;" |Albums ! colspan=5 style="background:#B0C4DE;" | Baaraan Toee (''You are the Rain'') (Official, Released: 2014)[https://www.i7radio.com/mp3/c/chaartaar/baaraan-toee Baaraan Toee at i7radio.com][https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/baaraan-toee/id821133151 Baaraan Toee] at [[ITunes Store]] |- style="text-align:center;" ! revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox road |country=EST |type=National |route=4 |maint= |map=Estonian-national-road-4-map-white.png |photo=Tallinna-Pärnu maantee 67km.jpg |length_km=192 |length_ref= |established= |direction_a= |terminus_a=[[Tallinn]] |junction=[[Image:AB-Kreuz-blau.svg|20px]] [[Image:M8-EE.svg|20px]] Tallinn
[[Image:AB-AS-blau.svg|20px]] Järvevana tee Tallinn
[[Image:AB-Kreuz-blau.svg|20px]] [[Image:B15-EE.svg|20px]] Tallinn
[[Image:AB-AS-blau.svg|20px]] [[Image:M11-EE.svg|20px]] Saue
[[Image:AB-AS-blau.svg|20px]] [[Image:M9-EE.svg|20px]] Ääsmäe
[[Image:AB-Kreuz-blau.svg|20px]] [[Image:B28-EE.svg|20px]] Orgita
[[Image:AB-Kreuz-blau.svg|20px]] Tallinna maantee Pärnu
[[Image:AB-AS-blau.svg|20px]] [[Image:M5-EE.svg|20px]] Pärnu
[[Image:AB-Kreuz-blau.svg|20px]] [[Image:B59-EE.svg|20px]] Pärnu
[[Image:AB-Kreuz-blau.svg|20px]] [[Image:M6-EE.svg|20px]] Uulu
[[Image:F22 1 1.svg|20px]] Border crossing to Latvia |direction_b= |terminus_b=[[Ikla]]
[[Image:A1-LV.svg|30px]] [[Image:E67-LV.svg|30px]] Ainaži, Latvia |cities=[[Tallinn]], [[Pärnu]] |previous_type=National |previous_route=3 |next_type=National |next_route=5 }} '''Põhimaantee 4''' (ofcl. abbr. '''T4''') is a 192-kilometre longhttps://teeregister.riik.ee/mnt/index/report/road/show.do?resultID=1cca065bf197065b59c958af0b0f11&reportID=0cca022bf197022b59c958af0b0f11 north-south national main road in Estonia. The route follows the same path as the [[European route E67]], also known as the Via Baltica. The highway starts in Tallinn. From there the main cities passed are Saue, Märjamaa and Pärnu. The highway ends in Ikla at the Latvian border. The road forms a major transport north-south transport route between [[Estonia]] and [[Central Europe|Central]]/[[Western Europe]]. In 2015, the highest traffic volumes were around Tallinn, with the AADT there being around 31 000. These are the highest figures in Estonia. The figures rise again around Pärnu, hovering around 10 000.http://www.mnt.ee/public/liiklusloendus/Lisa_6-8_2015.pdf The road is a [[dual carriageway]] for 14,1 kilometres. The section is between [[Laagri]] and [[Ääsmäe]]. The section between Ääsmäe and Kernu will be expanded to 2+1 in 2016-2017.https://riigihanked.riik.ee/register/hange/176118 Another section to be expanded is between Jänesselja and Nurme, also to be expanded to 2+1. ==Route description== The T4 is a major north-south highway in Estonia connecting the capital of the country, [[Tallinn]], to the fourth largest city in Estonia, [[Pärnu]], and ultimately the [[Latvia]]n border (where the Latvian [[A1 (Latvia)|A1]] continues to [[Riga]]). The T4 is a part of the [[European route E67]], also known as the Via Baltica. The route bypasses all cities and towns, only having a 13-kilometre stretch in Tallinn. The highway begins in Tallinn from Viru Väljak and runs through the city for 13 kilometres. In the city, it intersects with the T8 at Vabaduse väljak and the T15 at Järve. Shortly after crossing city borders, the road turns into a dual carriageway and interchanges with the T11 at Saue. At kilometre 27, the road meets with the T9 and turns into a 1+1 road. The road continues in a straight, southbound manner until Pärnu. At Pärnu, the road turns left onto the Pärnu bypass (with a 70 km/h speed limit). The road has an intersection with the T5 here and crosses the Pärnu river. After this, the road turns left again, and shortly after Pärnu intersects with the T6. Afterwards the route follows the Estonian coast until Ikla, where the Latvian border is crossed and the road continues as the [[A1 (Latvia)|A1]] in Latvia. Currently there are 11 speed cameras on the T4, between kilometres 92 and 141.http://www.mnt.ee/index.php?id=25085 ==See also== * [[Transport in Estonia]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscat-inline|Estonian national road 4|'''Estonian national road 4'''}} {{Highways in Estonia}} [[Category:Roads in Estonia|N4]] {{Europe-road-stub}} {{Estonia-transport-stub}}

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=July 2012}} [[File:Wood, Gar Mr., - NARA - 279714.jpg|thumb|Garfield Wood]] [[Image:gar wood.gif|right|thumb|300px|Gar Wood returns the [[Harmsworth Trophy]] to the United States in 1920]]
'''Garfield Arthur "Gar" Wood''' (December 4, 1880 – June 19, 1971) was an American [[inventor]], [[entrepreneur]], and championship [[motorboat]] builder and racer who held the world [[water speed record]] on several occasions. He was the first man to travel over 100 miles per hour on water.
==Early life== [[Image:Miss America 2 1921.JPG|thumb|right|300px|Miss America 2, 1921 [[Harmsworth Trophy]] winner]] Gar Wood was born on December 4, 1880 in [[Mapleton, Iowa|Mapleton]], [[Iowa]], into a family of 13 children.<ref Name=PM>{{cite journal| last=Fix| first=John| date=July 1967| title=Gar Wood: An Old Sea Dog Is Up to New Tricks| journal=[[Popular Mechanics]]| pages=82–85| url=https://books.google.com/?id=x9MDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA82&dq=gar+wood+boat| accessdate=7 July 2009}}</ref> His father was a ferryboat operator on [[Lake Osakis]], [[Minnesota]], and Gar worked on boats from an early age. In 1911, at age 31, he invented a [[hydraulic]] lift for unloading coal from rail trucks.
==Garwood Industries== He established the Wood Hoist Co. in [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], and soon became a successful businessman. Later, he changed the company's name to Garwood Industries, which built racing and pleasure boats under the "Gar Wood" brand, but also capitalized on experience with coal unloaders to successfully produce and market '''GarWood''' truck, bus and coach bodies. He had a home in [[Algonac, Michigan]], the same city as Christopher Smith, founder of [[Chris-Craft]] boats.
==Racing career== In 1916, Wood purchased a motorboat for racing called ''Miss Detroit''. Wood set a new [[water speed record]] of {{convert|74.870|mph|kph}} in 1920 on the [[Detroit River]], using a new boat called ''Miss America''. In the following twelve years, Wood built nine more ''Miss Americas'' and broke the record five times, raising it to {{convert|124.860|mph|kph}} in 1932 on the [[St. Clair River]].
In 1921, Wood raced one of his boats against the Havana Special train, {{convert|1250|mi|km}} up the [[Atlantic]] coast from [[Miami]] to [[New York City]]. Wood made the trip in 47 hours and 23 minutes and beat the train by 12 minutes. In 1925, he raced the [[Twentieth Century Limited]] train up the [[Hudson River]] between [[Albany, New York|Albany]] and New York and won by 22 minutes.
As well as being a record breaker and showman, Wood won five straight powerboat [[Gold Cup (motorsport)|Gold Cup]] races between 1917 and 1921. Wood also won the prestigious [[Harmsworth Trophy]] nine times (1920–21, 1926, 1928–30, 1932–33).
In 1931, he lost the Trophy in dramatic circumstances to his younger brother George. The race was held on the Detroit River and was billed as a match race between the Wood brothers and English (sic) racing driver and record-breaker [[Kaye Don]], driving ''[[Miss England II]]''. Before an estimated crowd of over a million spectators (one of the largest crowds for a sporting event ever), Don won the first heat of the race. In the second heat, Wood was leading Don, when ''Miss England II'' suddenly flipped over rounding one of the turns, fortunately without injury to Don and his co-driver. Gar Wood finished the race first, but both he and Don were disqualified because they had jumped the starter's gun by seven seconds. George Wood completed the final race to win the trophy.
In April, 1936, Wood, along with many other sports champions and stand outs, was honored at a banquet in [[Detroit, MI]].<ref name=Star>{{cite news| title=Sport Gossip| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Qg8_AAAAIBAJ&sjid=jk4MAAAAIBAJ&pg=6215%2C5649943| last=Degeer| first=Vern| work=[[Windsor Star|Windsor Daily Star]]| date=20 April 1936| accessdate=2014-12-09}}</ref> This banquet was the first celebration of [[Champions Day]].
In July, 1936, a plaque was presented to Detroit from the White House honoring Detroit as the City of Champions.<ref name=TC>{{cite news| title=City of Champions Night at Fairgrounds| url=https://newspaperarchive.com/traverse-city-record-eagle/1936-06-29/page-26| work=[[Traverse City Record-Eagle]]| date=29 June 1936| page=26| accessdate=2014-12-08}}</ref> The plaque has five "medallions" featuring athletes. One of these medallions is of a power boat racer, representing Wood.<ref name=Pitt>{{cite news| title=Louis' Name Is Stricken From Champions' Plaque| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=RUQbAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Nk4EAAAAIBAJ&pg=4049,3081736&dq=city+of+champions+plaque&hl=en| work=[[Pittsburgh Press|The Pittsburgh Press]]| agency=[[United Press International|The United Press]]| date=21 June 1936| accessdate=2014-12-09}}</ref>
==Later business career== Wood retired from racing in 1933 to concentrate on his businesses. Garwood Industries continued to build wooden racing and pleasure boats until 1947 under the "Gar Wood" brand. Boats were sized between 16ft and 33ft in length; the most famous models were the 16ft [[Gar Wood Speedster]] (built from 1934 to 1938) and the exclusive 33’ Baby Gar gentleman’s racer (built in the 1920s and early 1930s).<ref>https://www.garwood.com/index.php/gar-wood-history/</ref> Garwood Industries also built truck bodies and winches that were used extensively by truck manufacturers such as [[International Harvester]], and were an [[Original equipment manufacturer|OEM]] supplier to both the civilian and military market. Many trucks built during [[World War II]] came equipped with Garwood bodies and winches. One of the biggest contributions by Garwood Industries was the development of the now-ubiquitous [[garbage truck]], which was originally built and sold under the name [[Garwood Load Packer]].
==Inventions== Wood was known as an inventive genius who, at one point, held more US [[patents]] than any other living American.{{cn|date=November 2017}}
In 1897, at age 17, he invented a downdraft [[carburetor]] which enabled his inspection boat to outrace the other inspectors.{{cn|date=June 2017}}
In 1911 or 1912 he invented the profitable hydraulic hoist for dump trucks. He used the money It earned to build racing boats which won many championships between 1917 and 1933.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZLIJ4zw9370C&pg=PA30&dq=%22Garfield+wood%22 |title=The World's Fastest Boats |page=30 |website=[[Google Books]]}}</ref>
At one point he had a job selling lightning rods to farmers, and to demonstrate their effectiveness he invented an [[induction coil]] device to mimic lightning.<ref>{{cite magazine |quote=He sold lightning rods to farmers. He invented an induction-coil device to demonstrate their effectiveness |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FtUXAQAAMAAJ&q=Garfield+wood+lightning+rod |title=Popular Mechanics |volume=128 |publisher=Popular Mechanics Company |series=[[Industrial arts]]}}</ref>
==Retirement and later years== In the 1950s, Wood acquired [[Fisher Island (Florida)|Fisher Island]] in South [[Florida]]'s [[Biscayne Bay]], the last of a series of millionaires to occupy it as a one-family island retreat. He sold it to a development group in 1963. Wood also had a summer retreat in McGregor Bay, Ontario.
A 1967 Popular Mechanics article <ref name="PM" /> showed even in retirement Wood was still active inventing an Electric Vehicle (EV) controller, which he used in the EV he built.
Wood died in [[Miami, Florida|Miami]] 16 Jun 1971, at age 90 and days before the 50th anniversary of his first Harmsworth win. Upon his death, George Van of [[The Detroit News]] wrote: ''“To the public, he was [[Tom Swift]], [[Jules Verne]], [[Frank Merriwell]] with a little bit of [[Horatio Alger]] thrown in.”''<ref name=News>{{cite news |title=Gar Wood — Speedboat King |url=http://www.thunderboats.org/history/history0511.html |first1=Vivian M. |last1=Baulch |first2=Pam |last2=Shermeyer |work=The Detroit News |date=18 February 1996 |publisher=The Hydroplane & Raceboat Museum |accessdate=2014-12-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120831004822/http://www.thunderboats.org/history/history0511.html |archivedate=2012-08-31 |df= }}</ref> Wood was buried near his home in Algonac, Michigan.
==Award== He was inducted in the [[Motorsports Hall of Fame of America]] in 1990.
==References== <references/>
== External links == {{Commons category|Gar Wood}} *[http://www.coachbuilt.com/bui/g/gar_wood/gar_wood.htm Garwood Industries in Coachbuilt] * [http://www.classicboat.com/antique-boats-28-garwood-33h.htm 1929 28' "Baby Gar" Antique Boat] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=XSgDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA20&dq=Popular+Science+1931+plane&hl=en&ei=XeARTe7ZJ4alnQf84KjpDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAzgU#v=onepage&q&f=true "The Speediest Craft Afloat", June 1929, Popular Science] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=xd8DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA536&dq=%22Popular+Mechanics%22+Jan+1935+floating&hl=en&ei=Wtc4TsGsDeSusAKXtpka&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&sqi=2&ved=0CFUQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q&f=true "The Gadget King of America" ''Popular Mechanics'', October 1934, pp 536-539] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=ud4DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA407&dq=Popular+Science+1935+plane+%22Popular+Mechanics%22&hl=en&ei=hKgrTpn_EeWssQLa5sW7Cw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&sqi=2&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q&f=true "Gar Wood's Mystery Boat" ''Popular Mechanics'', September 1935] '''Miss America X''' * [https://archive.is/20130121130859/http://info.detnews.com/history/story/index.cfm?id=126&category=sports Detroit News retrospective] * [http://www.garwood.com Gar Wood Society] * [http://www.garwoodspeedster.com Gar Wood Speedster Collection] * [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gar_Wood_Speedster Gar Wood Speedster] * [http://www.bluebird-electric.net/miss_america.htm Garfield (Gar) Wood] * [https://books.google.com/?id=x9MDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA82&dq=gar+wood+boat 1967 July Popular Mechanics article on Gar Wood's Electric Vehicle (EV) ] pages=82–85
{{Authority control}}

page.title: Honorary Medal for Merits toward Museum Collections

revision.comment: /* top */replaced: a Honorary Medal → an honorary medal using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox Military Award |name=Museum Medal |image= |caption= |awarded_by=[[Image:Flag of the Netherlands.svg|18px]] [[Kingdom of the Netherlands]] |type= [[Civil decoration]],
with degrees gold, silver and bronze |eligibility= |for= |status=Currently awarded |description= |clasps= |established=26 June 1817 |first_award= |last_award= |total= |posthumous= |recipients= |individual= |higher=[[The Ruyter Medal]] |lower= [[Flood disaster Medal]] |image2= Ribbon bar golden Dutch Museum Medal.jpg |image_size2= 85px |caption2=Ribbon bar of the golden Dutch Museum Medal }} The '''Honorary Medal for Merits toward Museum Collections''' ({{lang-nl|Erepenning voor Verdiensten jegens Openbare Verzamelingen}}), also known as the '''Museum Medal''' ({{lang-nl|Museummedaille}}), is one of the oldest [[civil decoration]]s of the [[Kingdom of the Netherlands|Netherlands]]. It was created by royal decree on 26 June 1817 by [[King William I of the Netherlands]]. The decree describes the following: "Erepenning voor blijken van belangstelling in 's Rijksverzamelingen door schenking betoond" ({{lang-en|an honorary medal for appearance of interest in the state collection by donation shown}}). The medal is awarded in gold, silver or bronze as a token of appreciation to those who "aan hen, die enig boek- of kunstwerk, dat de vrucht van hun arbeid was, de Koning deden toekomen" ({{lang-en|for those, who donate to the Dutch monarch any works of art, that were collected with much effort}}). By royal decree, on 5 May 1877, eligibility for this award was extended by [[King William III of the Netherlands]], with the description "aan hen, die door het aanbieden van belangrijke geschenken of op andere wijze zich verdienstelijk hebben gemaakt ten opzichte van de verschillende wetenschappelijke en kunstverzamelingen des Rijks" ({{lang-en|to those who donated important works of art to the state museums or who showed praiseworthy acts regarding the different scientific collections or art collection of the state museums}}). Due to this description, the medal obtained its current official name. However, since the end of the 19th century, this decoration is primarily known as the "Museum Medal". Up until 1897, the honorary medal was only a standing decoration, when [[Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands]] declared that the medal could be worn suspended from a ribbon. Eligibility for this award was once again extending, by Queen Wilhelmina, on 28 October 1919 with the description "verdiensten jegens gemeentelijke (openbare) verzamelingen" (English: merit towards community (public) collections). What was initially a medal for generous donors became now an official royal award for merit. [[Queen Juliana of the Netherlands]] decided by royal decree on 26 July 1952 that the shape of the medal and ribbon should be changed. The current ribbon is orange with two red lines descending down the middle. A ribbon bar is also given with the award, with a palm branch device in either gold or silver for recipients of the gold or silver versions of the medal, respectively. [[Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands]] later changed the composition of the medallion, and is now depicted on the obverse of the medal. ==Notable recipients== * [[Willem, Baron van Dedem]] - art collector *[[Rudi Fuchs]] - Dutch art historian and former director of the [[Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam]] *Dollie Defesche-Bakker - widow of Pieter Defesche, a former Dutch visual artist *Rosetta C. Musaph-Andriesse - former director of the [[Joods Historisch Museum|Jewish Historical Museum]] Amsterdam *A.W. Swaanswijk-Koek - widow of [[Lucebert]], a former Dutch painter *Johan Wertheim - a Dutch sculptor *A.R. Wittop Koning - a Dutch architect [[Category:Orders, decorations, and medals of the Netherlands]] [[Category:1817 establishments in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Awards established in 1817]] {{odm-stub}} {{Netherlands-stub}}

'''INTELSAT 34''' or '''IS-34''' is [[communications satellite]] built on [[Space Systems/Loral]]'s [[SSL 1300|1300-series]] satellite platform. The satellite broadcasts television to homes in Brazil, distributes video programming for companies like [[HBO]] and [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] across Latin America, and beams [[Satellite Internet access|Internet broadband services]] to travelers aboard airplanes and ships crossing the North Atlantic Ocean.
Intelsat 34, unlike its predecessor, does not include the UHF-band that Intelsat had been unable to sell to its intended customer, the [[U.S. Department of Defense]].
== Launch == Intelsat 34 is the 50th Loral-built satellite launched for Intelsat. With a launch mass of 7,275 pounds - about 3.3 metric tons - Intelsat 34 is a replacement for the [[Intelsat 27]] spacecraft lost aboard a [[Sea Launch]] mission in 2013. It took over service from the Galaxy 11 and Intelsat 805 spacecraft in orbit, the company's last two relay stations that had been launched before 2000.

{{Infobox book | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Novels or Wikipedia:WikiProject_Books --> | name = Karnak Café | image = | caption = | title_orig = Al-Karnak الكرنك | orig_lang_code = ar | translator = [[Roger Allen (translator)|Roger Allen]] (Anchor Books, 2007) | cover_artist = | author = [[Naguib Mahfouz]] | genre = [[Fiction]], [[Literature]], [[Egyptian Literature]], [[Arabic Literature]] | publisher = | pub_date = 1974 | media_type = Print ([[paperback]]) | pages = 112 pp }} '''''Karnak Café''''' (''Al-Karnak'', [[Arabic]]: الكرنك) is a [[novella]] written in 1974 by [[Egypt]]ian writer [[Naguib Mahfouz]], winner of the [[Nobel Prize in Literature]] in 1988. The novel was made into a [[Karnak (film)|film of the same name]] in 1975. Set against the discussions between the patrons of a café in [[Cairo]], the ''Karnak Café'', the book follows the stories of three individuals during the 1960s, including the [[Six-Day War]] (1967) and the [[War of Attrition]] (1967–70). It therein explores some of the political currents vying for control over Egyptian politics in the 1960s as well as political persecution, the deep state, and state violence.
== Plot summary == The narrator begins the story by describing how he originally discovered the ''Karnak Café'' in Cairo, attracted by the quiet charms of Qurunfula, a bellydancer of former fame and the café's owner. There, the narrator quickly becomes part of the café's regular crowd of patrons, which represent a cross-section of Egyptian society during the early 1960s. Among many others, the crowd includes the following young people: Hilmi Hamada, an idealistic [[communist]] with whom Qurunfula has a discreet love affair; Isma'il al-Shaykh, a law graduate of modest origins; and Zaynab Diyab, another graduate from a poor background. Throughout the story, the youth are repeatedly arrested and imprisoned for prolonged periods; a mirror to Qurunfula's despair, the narrator keeps track how the youths' initial political enthusiasm and optimism slowly gives place to disillusion and hopelessness. After their third prison term, the café learns that Hilmi Hamada has died in prison, leaving Qurunfula distraught. As Isma'il and Zaynab open up to the narrator, he learns of the horrors Isma'il and Zaynab endured in prison – Isma'il is repeatedly tortured while Zaynab is raped – and how the ruthless and brutal police officer Khalid Sawfan turned both Isma'il and Zaynab into informants for the secret police after their second term in prison. As Hilmi tries to convince Isma'il and Zaynab of the necessity of communism, he is betrayed by Zaynab, who tries to thereby keep Isma'il safe, and is beaten to death in prison. The defeat of the Egyptian army during the [[Six-Day War]] sees Isma'il, who was imprisoned in spite of Zaynab's assistance, and a reversal of fortunes: after being thrown into prison and having become disabled through torture, Sawfan joins the regular crowd of the Karnak Café, painting himself both as a criminal and a victim and gaining the patrons' appreciation through witty political commentary. The novel ends on a hopeful note with Qurunfula setting her eyes upon Munir Ahmad, a new idealistic and innocent youth: for purity and innocence never disappear forever.
== External links == * [http://www.aucpress.com/p-4809-karnak-caf.aspx ''Karnak Café'' on the website of the American University of Cairo Press]

It is named after the nickname of [[Al-Abbas ibn Ali]], son of [[Imam Ali]]. The group was formed in late 2012 to defend the [[Sayyidah Zaynab Mosque]] and other Shia holy sites in Syria.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-syria-crisis-shiites-idUSBRE92202X20130303|title=Shi'ite fighters rally to defend Damascus shrine|date=3 March 2013|publisher=|accessdate=29 September 2016|via=Reuters}} It rose in prominence in reaction to the desecration of various shrines, heritage sites, and places of worship by rebels during the [[Syrian civil war]] and subsequently collaborated with the [[Syrian Army]]. Its fighters include native Shia [[Damascus|Damascenes]], Damascus-based [[Iraq]]i Shia refugees, Iraqi Shia volunteers, and other foreign Shia volunteers. Iraqis form its primary constituent.{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtoninstitute.org/policy-analysis/view/irans-foreign-legion-the-role-of-iraqi-shiite-militias-in-syria|title=Iran's Foreign Legion: The Role of Iraqi Shiite Militias in Syria|publisher=|accessdate=29 September 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://jihadology.net/2014/06/18/hizballah-cavalcade-from-najaf-to-damascus-and-onto-baghdad-iraqs-liwa-abu-fadl-al-abbas/|title=Hizballah Cavalcade: From Najaf to Damascus and Onto Baghdad: Iraq’s Liwa Abu Fadl al-Abbas|first=|last=phillsmyth|date=18 June 2014|publisher=|accessdate=29 September 2016}} It fights primarily around Damascus, but has fought in [[Aleppo]] as well.{{cite web|url=http://www.almasdarnews.com/article/more-iraqi-paramilitary-arrive-in-aleppo-under-orders-from-the-iranian-revolutionary-guard/|title=More Iraqi Paramilitary Arrive in Aleppo Under Orders from the Iranian Revolutionary Guard|first=Leith|last=Fadel|date=26 October 2015|publisher=|accessdate=29 September 2016}} In May and June 2013, Reuters reported a split had developed within the brigade over finances and leadership which erupted into a gunbattle. Many non-Syrian members subsequently formed a different brigade.{{cite news|title=Iraqi Shi'ites flock to Assad's side as sectarian split widens|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSBRE95I0ZA20130619 |publisher=Reuters|date=19 June 2013|accessdate=18 September 2014}} On 19 May 2014, fighters from the [[Harakat Nour al-Din al-Zenki|Nour al-Din al-Zanki Brigade]] claimed to have taken over the al-Abbas Brigade's regional headquarters in Aleppo.{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U5N7p38Xpjs news|title=Hezbollah displacing Iraqi Shiite fighters in Syria|url=http://yalibnan.com/2014/06/14/hezbollah-displacing-iraqi-shiite-fighters-syria/ |publisher=Ya Libnan|date=14 June 2014|accessdate=18 [[Conservative liberalism]]
[[Movement for unification of Romania and Moldova|Moldovan-Romanian unionism]] |position = [[Center-right]] |international = ''None'' |european = ''None'' |colours = Yellow, Blue |seats1_title = [[Parliament of the Republic of Moldova|Parliament]] |seats1 = {{Composition bar|0|101|hex=#FFE600}} |seats2_title = [[Administrative divisions of Moldova|District]] Presidents |seats2 = {{Composition bar|0|32|hex=#FFE600}} |website = [http://www.pnl.md/ pnl.md/] }} The '''National Liberal Party''' ({{lang-ro|Partidul Național Liberal}}, '''PNL''') is an active non-parliamentary [[political party]] in the [[Moldova|Republic of Moldova]]. It was founded in 1993, but temporarily disappeared through [[merger (politics)|political amalgamation]] in 2000, before being refounded in 2006. It is not officially recognized by of the [[National Liberal Party (Romania)|National Liberal Party of Romania]], therefore it does not have the right to share the historical tradition of the [[Greater Romania|prewar]] party of the same name which was forcibly dissolved in 1947 in [[Socialist Republic of Romania|post-war Romania]] by the [[Romanian Communist Party]] after the [[Soviet occupation of Bessarabia and Northern Bukovina|reannexation of Bessarabia]]. == Political agenda == The party supports the [[Unification of Romania and Moldova|unification of the Republic of Moldova with Romania]] and shares copies the identity and ideology of the traditional party in neighbouring Romania. Nonetheless, very much unlike the Romanian PNL (which is dominant on the centre-right as well as [[List of political parties in Romania|Romania's second largest political party]]), the Moldovan PNL might actually be considered a [[Minor party|micro party]] with respect to [[Politics of Moldova|Moldovan politics]]. In addition to support for [[political union]] with Romania, as an interim measure, the PNL supports [[Moldova and the European Union|EU]] and [[Moldova and NATO|NATO]] membership for Moldova. == Electoral history == {|class=wikitable style="text-align: right;" width=70% |- ! {{More citations needed|date=June 2018}}{{MOS|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox law enforcement agency |agencyname = National Police Chiefs' Council |nativenamea = |nativenamer = |commonname = |abbreviation = NPCC |patch = |patchcaption = |logo = |logocaption = |badge = |badgecaption = |flag = |flagcaption = |motto = |mottotranslated = |formedyear = 2015 |formedmonthday = April 1 |dissolved = |preceding1 = |preceding2 = |preceding3 = |preceding4 = |preceding5 = |employees = |volunteers = |budget = |legalpersonality= |country = United Kingdom |countryabbr = UK |national = |map = |mapcaption = |sizearea = |sizepopulation = |legaljuris = |governingbody = |governingbodyscnd = |constitution1 = |overviewtype = |overviewbody = |headquarters = 1st Floor, 10 Victoria Street, London SW1H 0NN |hqlocmap = |hqlocleft = |hqloctop = |hqlocmappoptitle = |sworntype = |sworn = |unsworntype = |unsworn = |electeetype = |minister1name = |minister1pfo = |chief1name = [[Sara Thornton (police officer)|Sara Thornton]] |chief1position = Chair |parentagency = |child1agency = |unittype = |unitname = |officetype = |officename = |provideragency = |uniformedas = |stationtype = |stations = |airbases = |lockuptype = |lockups = |vehicle1type = |vehicles1 = |boat1type = |boats1 = |aircraft1type = |aircraft1 = |animal1type = |animals1 = |person1name = |person1reason = |person1type = |programme1 = |activity1name = |activitytype = |anniversary1 = |award1 = |website = https://www.npcc.police.uk/ |footnotes = |reference = }} The '''National Police Chiefs' Council''' ('''NPCC''') is a national coordination body for [[Law enforcement in the United Kingdom|law enforcement in the United Kingdom]] and the representative body for British police chief officers. Established on 1 April 2015, it replaced the former [[Association of Chief Police Officers]] (ACPO), following the [[Association of Chief Police Officers#Parker Review|Parker Review]] of the operations of ACPO.
== History ==
The NPCC was established on 1 April 2015 as the replacement organisation of the [[Association of Chief Police Officers]].
In 2010, the [[First Cameron ministry|Cameron Government]] announced a series of police reforms including local accountability through [[Police and Crime Commissioners]], and the creation of the [[National Crime Agency]] and the [[College of Policing]]. In 2013, the PCCs commissioned General Sir [[Nick Parker]] to review the services that ACPO provided and make recommendations about the requirements of a national policing body following the fundamental changes in policing.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-24945596|title= Acpo overhaul needed, says general's report for PCCs|publisher=BBC News|date=14 November 2013}}</ref> In 2014, a group of chief officers and PCCs began working together to implement Parker's recommendations and develop a national body. Chief officers voted in support of the group's proposals in July 2014. Chief Constable Sara Thornton was appointed to chair the NPCC on 2 December 2014. ACPO was closed down on 31 March 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apccs.police.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/Independent-review-of-ACPO.pdf|title=Independent review of ACPO|author=Nick Parker|date=2013|accessdate=27 June 2015}}</ref>
In October 2018 the NPCC threatened to take legal action in the high court against the government's plans to cut hundreds of millions of pounds from police funding. The Treasury plans to increase the money each force pays to the police pension scheme. This would involve forces paying a £420m bill, as well as the 19% cut to police funding since 2010. Police chiefs maintain reductions have make it hard for fores to protect the public. Leaders of three of the biggest forces fear officer levels will drop to those of the 1970s. The NPCC fears if the £420m bill is dealt with only by cutting police numbers, this will mean 10,000 fewer officers.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/oct/30/police-threaten-tories-with-legal-action-over-forces-budget-cuts Police to sue government unless it backs down over cuts] ''[[The Guardian]]''</ref>
== Structure and membership == The NPCC is founded by a legal agreement between chief constables, [[Police and Crime Commissioners]], and non-Home Office police force equivalents under Section 22A of the [[Police Act 1996]]. It is hosted by the [[Metropolitan Police Service]] (MPS) but acts independently.<ref name=NPCA>{{cite web|url=http://www.npcc.police.uk/documents/NPCC%20Section%2022a%20Agreement.pdf|title=National Police Collaboration Agreement – in relation to the setting up of a Co-ordinating Body known as the National Police Chiefs’ Council ("NPCC")|publisher=National Police Chiefs' Council|author=Eversheds LLP|accessdate=27 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.npcc.police.uk/releases/business-begins-at-the-national-police-chiefs-council|title=Business begins at the National Police Chiefs’ Council|date=1 April 2015|publisher=National Police Chiefs' Council}}</ref>{{Primary source inline|date=June 2018}}
The NPCC brings together and is funded by police forces in England, Wales and Northern Ireland as well as the armed services and some British overseas territories. It draws on the efforts and expertise of chief officers: those ranked Assistant Chief Constable and above, or Commander and above in MPS and [[City of London Police]], and senior police staff equivalents. It coordinates police forces' collective operational responses to national threats such as terrorism, organised crime and national emergencies.
The current chair of the National Police Chiefs’ Council is [[Sara Thornton (police officer)|Sara Thornton]], [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire|CBE]], [[Queen's Police Medal|QPM]], formerly Chief Constable of the [[Thames Valley Police]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-30277356|title=Sara Thornton to lead National Police Chiefs' Council|date=1 December 2014|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> Chief Constable of [[Sussex Police]] Giles York and MPS Assistant Commissioner Martin Hewitt support her as Vice-chairs in addition to their day jobs as chief officers within forces.
=== Chief Constables' Council === The Chief Constables' Council is the senior operational decision-making body for the National Police Chiefs' Council. Every police force is represented in the work of the NPCC through the Chief Constables' Council.
The Chief Constables’ Council is the primary decision-making forum for the NPCC. Chief constables (and equivalents) meet quarterly to discuss operational policing issues and agree action. Working with the College of Policing, the council takes decisions on national standards and common approaches with the aim of protecting the public from the most serious and strategic threats.
===Coordination committees=== In addition to their day jobs, chief officers support the NPCC's work by providing national operational perspectives on particular crime and policing issues. There are eleven broad coordination committees, each led by a chief officer. Within each area, chief officers may also lead on specific issues - for example, under the Crime Operations Coordination Committee there are individual leads for domestic abuse, rape, drugs and cyber-crime. The coordination committees cover:
* Crime Operations * Criminal Justice * Equality, Diversity and Human Rights * Finance * Information Management * International Coordination * Local Policing * Operations * Performance Management * Workforce * Counter terrorism (chaired by [[Metropolitan Police Service]] Assistant Commissioner and responsible for the [[National Counter Terrorism Policing Network]])
Coordination committees work closely with the [[College of Policing]] to assist in the development of professional practice for police officers in different areas of policing. Representatives from the Government and other stakeholders in the criminal justice system and third sector are involved in the committees’ work to include a range of perspectives.
== Projects == The NPCC operates and/or collaborates with the following police projects:
* [[ACRO Criminal Records Office]] (ACRO) * [[AVCIS Vehicle Crime Intelligence Service]] (AVCIS) * [[National Ballistics Intelligence Service]] (NABIS) * [[National Domestic Extremism and Disorder Intelligence Unit]] (NDEDIU) * [[National Police Coordination Centre]] (NPoCC) * [[National Police Freedom of Information and Data Protection Unit]] (NPFDU) * [[National Wildlife Crime Unit]] (NWCU) * [[Secured by Design]] * [[UK National Counter Terrorism Policing HQ]] (NCTP HQ)
== See also == * [[Operation Hydrant]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * {{Official|http://www.npcc.police.uk/}}

'''Nizamski rastanak''' ([[Serbian Cyrillic alphabet|Serbian Cyrillic]]: Низамски растанак) is a famous Serbian song. According to [[Felix Kanitz]], because the melody was played by the [[Ottoman military]] [[orchestra]]s when the Ottomans left [[Principality of Serbia|Serbia]] in May 1867, this melody became one of the most favorite Serb melodies.{{cite book|last1=Damjanović|first1=Ratomir Rale|last2=Tomić|first2=Novo|last3=Ćosić|first3=Sanja|title=Serbia--srpski narod, srpska zemlja, srpska duhovnost u delima stranih autora : pesme i poeme, pripovetke, romani, drame, putopisi, besede, dnevnici, memoari, eseji, pisma, zapisi|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lnItAQAAIAAJ|year=2000|publisher=Itaka}}{{cite book|title=Zbornik Istorijskog muzeja Srbije|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xlxpAAAAMAAJ|year=1998|publisher=Muzej|page=326}} This melody was regularly played by [[Armed forces of the Principality of Serbia|Serbian military]] orchestras during [[World War I]] and was part of an emotional reception of the victory of Serbian army on the [[Macedonian Front]].{{harv|Jergović|2004|p=577}}: "Nizamski rastanak, melodija koju su svirali orkestri srpske kraljevske vojske za Prvoga svjetskog rata, i bila je dio solunaškoga emocionalnog kataloga." After the war, this song became part of the repertoire of Serb [[romanticist]]s and [[Serbian nationalism|nationalists]] and was regularly sung during their gatherings.{{harv|Jergović|2004|p=577}} In 1995, [[Benjamin Isović]] used the melody of "Nizamski rastanak" to write the Bosniak song "Šehidski rastanak", believing that he was only bringing back this melody to its Bosnian birth place.{{harv|Jergović|2004|p=577}} [[Miljenko Jergović]] considers the Bosnian origin of the melody as completely uncertain.{{harv|Jergović|2004|p=577}}: ".... istina sasvim neizvesnoj, postojbini. {| !Serbian Latin !Serbian Cyrillic !English
''Translation by [[Djuradj Vujcic]]'' |- || Skupite se svi, dobri drugovi neka truba dok ne padne mrak, svira rastanak. Poslednju našu pesmu vojničku zapevajmo složno svi nek' se sve ori. Pa za one prošle dane, nek' ti neka suza kane pa zar nismo bili mi, dobri drugovi. Ko da žali noći, ko da žali dane rastanak se sprema a vremena nema oj, druže moj. Još u srcu mom kao teški zvon odjekuje tužne trube glas, kroz taj garnizon. Poslednji, tužni pozdrav vojnički zapevajmo složno svi nek' se sve ori. Neka svaka cura čuje šta joj vojnik poručuje sad kad služba prestaje, kad se rastaje. Ludo živim sada, čudna tuga vlada uspomena davna iz vojničkih dana, oj, druže moj. || Скупите се сви, добри другови нека труба док не падне мрак, свира растанак. Последњу нашу песму војничку запевајмо сложно сви нек' се све ори. Па за оне прошле дане, нек' ти нека суза кане па зар нисмо били ми, добри другови. Ко да жали ноћи, ко да жали дане растанак се спрема а времена нема ој, друже мој. Још у срцу мом као тешки звон одјекује тужне трубе глас, кроз тај гарнизон. Последњи, тужни поздрав војнички запевајмо сложно сви нек' се све ори. Нека свака цура чује шта јој војник поручује сад кад служба престаје, кад се растаје. Лудо живим сада, чудна туга влада успомена давна из војничких дана, ој, друже мој. || Get together now, my good friends may the trumpet play until night sets, signalling our departure. Our last soldier’s song let’s all sing, may it be heard. Well for those old days, you can let out a tear were we not good friends. Who yearns for the nights, who yearns for the days the departure is preparing but there is no time oh, good friend. Still in my heart, like a hardened bell are heard the sounds of a sad trumpet, through that garrison. The last, sad soldier’s greeting let’s all sing, may it be heard. May every girl hear what a soldier recommends to her now when the service ends, when we all depart. I live madly now, a strange sadness is present a distant memory from my soldier’s days, oh, good friend. |} ==References== {{reflist}} == Sources == * {{cite book|ref=harv|last=Jergović|first=Miljenko|title=Inšallah Madona, inšallah|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wtBiAAAAMAAJ|year=2004|publisher=Durieux|isbn=978-953-188-200-2}} {{song-stub}} {{Serbia-stub}} [[Category:Serbian patriotic songs]] [[Category:Serbian soldiers]] [[Category:Military history of Serbia]]

{{Infobox organization |name = Priatelia Zeme – SPZ |bgcolor = |fgcolor = |image = |image_border = |size = |alt = |caption = |map = |msize = |malt = |mcaption = |map2 = |abbreviation = |motto = |predecessor = |successor = |formation = {{Start date and age|1996}} |extinction = |type = [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]] |status = |purpose = [[natural environment|environment]], [[waste reduction]] |headquarters = [[Košice]] |location = |coords = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> |region_served = [[Slovakia]] |membership = |language = |general =| |leader_title = Chairman |leader_name = [[Martin Valentovič]] |leader_title2 = Vice-chairman |leader_name2 = Branislav Moňok |leader_title3 = Project manager |leader_name3 = Lenka Beznáková |leader_title4 = |leader_name4 = |key_people = |main_organ = |parent_organization = [[Friends of the Earth International]] |affiliations = |budget = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |website = {{URL|www.priateliazeme.sk/spz/ }} |remarks = |former name = }} '''Priatelia Zeme – SPZ''' ([[Slovak language|Slovak]], translated to [[English language|English]] as ''Friends of the Earth - SPZ'') is a non-profit organisation protecting [[Natural environment|environment]] and [[nature]] in [[Slovakia]] and [[Europe]] since 1996. '''Priatelia Zeme – SPZ''' leads campaigns in the area of [[waste management]] and works on relating to [[waste]], such as natural resources consumption, [[toxic substances]] use and disposal, effects of [[incinerators]] and packaging issues. They are independent from any government or political parties.
== Scope of work ==
* information and education (information campaigns, workshops, trainings, lectures...) * campaigns to stop harmful activities * help to municipalities and towns in reducing the amount of waste and development of separate waste collection * projects to implement sustainable solutions (e.g. [[wikt:Separation|separation]], [[composting]], [[recycling]], [[waste reduction]]) * research, monitoring * legislative changes
The most remarkable membership of Priatelia Zeme – SPZ represents their work in environmental organization [[Priatelia Zeme Slovensko|Friends of Earth Slovakia]], which is a member of [[Friends of the Earth International]] (FoEI).
== External links == * [http://www.priateliazeme.sk/spz http://www.priateliazeme.sk/spz]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Priatelia Zeme - SPZ}} [[Category:Environmental organisations based in Slovakia]] [[Category:Friends of the Earth]] [[Category:International environmental organizations]]

[[File:Psalter World Map, c.1265.jpg|thumb|Psalter world map, ca. 1260]]
'''Psalter World Map''' is the name historiography gave to a medieval world map that has been found in a [[psalter]]. This ''[[mappa mundi]]'' is now conserved at the [[British Library]] in London.
The small map (c. {{convert|9.5|cm|in|abbr=on|disp=or}} high) shows a lot of detail. It was written around 1260; the author is unknown. According to historian Anna-Dorothee von den Brincken, it looks like a small version of the [[Ebstorf Map]] from Northern Germany.
It is a typical ''mappa mundi'' that does not only show the geographical and historical knowledge, but also puts it into the frame of [[salvation]] history. Jesus Christ appears in the East (i.e. "above"), as the maps of Christian [[Middle Ages]] have East above, not North, giving a blessing with his right hand.
An open-access high-resolution digital image of the map with place and name annotations is included among the thirteen medieval maps of the world edited in the [[Virtual Mappa]] project.
==General references== *{{cite book |first=Anna-Dorothee |last=von den Brincken |title=Fines Terrae. Die Enden der Erde und der vierte Kontinent auf mittelalterlichen Weltkarten |series=[[Monumenta Germaniae Historica|MGH]]-Schriften |volume=36 |location=Hannover |publisher=Hahnsche Buchhandlung |year=1992 |isbn=3-7752-5436-6 }}
== External links == *[http://www.bl.uk/magnificentmaps/map1.html Psalter map, c. 1265] Deep zoom feature, highlighted details. Video introduction from Peter Barber, Head of Maps at the British Library. *[http://sims.digitalmappa.org/workspace/#965fe731 Virtual Mappa], eds. Martin Foys, Heather Wacha et al. Schoenberg Institute of Manuscript Studies, 2018: an open-access digital edition of thirteen medieval maps of the world, including the Psalter Map.
[[Category:Historic maps of the world]] [[Category:Illuminated psalters|World map]] [[Category:Works of unknown authorship]] [[Category:British Library collections]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox officeholder | image = Richard H. Ledgett.jpg | caption = | order1 = 18th | title1 = [[Deputy Director of the National Security Agency]] | term_start1 = 2014 | term_end1 = 2017 | president1 = [[Barack Obama]]
[[Donald Trump]] | predecessor1 = [[John C. Inglis]] | successor1 = [[George C. Barnes]] | birth_date = | birth_place = | alma_mater = | allegiance = {{flag|United States of America}} | branch = {{army|USA|size=23px}} | unit = Signals Intelligence | commands = | battles = | awards = | relations = }} '''Richard H. Ledgett Jr.''' is a former Deputy Director of the [[National Security Agency]].{{cite web |url=https://www.nsa.gov/news-features/press-room/press-releases/2014/new-deputy-director-rick-ledgett.shtml |title=2014 Press Release – NSA's New Deputy Director |publisher=NSA.gov |date= |accessdate=2014-02-01}} ==Education== Ledgett has an undergraduate degree in psychology and a graduate degree in strategic intelligence. ==Career== In 1988, he began working for the National Security Agency, where he served in a variety of positions in the cybersecurity division. Previous positions at NSA included Deputy Director for Analysis and Production (2009–2010), Deputy Director for Data Acquisition (2006–2009), Assistant Deputy Director for Data Acquisition (2005–2006), and Chief, NSA/CSS Pacific (2002–2005). From 2012 to 2013 he was the Director of the NSA/CSS Threat Operations Center, responsible for round-the-clock cryptologic activities to discover and counter adversary cyber efforts. From June 2013 to his appointment as Deputy Director in January 2014, Ledgett headed the investigation of leaks regarding [[PRISM (surveillance program)|NSA surveillance programs]] made by [[Edward Snowden]].{{cite web |url=http://www.nsa.gov/about/leadership/bio_ledgett.shtml |title=Biography Deputy Director of the NSA – NSA/CSS |publisher=NSA.gov |date= |accessdate=2014-02-01}} On February 3, 2017, Ledgett announced that he would be retiring in the spring.{{cite news|last1=Geller|first1=Eric|title=NSA deputy director resigning this spring|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/02/nsa-deputy-director-resigning-richard-leggett-234636|work=Politico|date=February 3, 2017}} His successor was [[George C. Barnes]].{{cite web |url=https://www.nsa.gov/about/leadership/ |title=Current Leadership |publisher=NSA.gov |date= |accessdate=2017-06-28}} On August 15, 2017, Ledgett was elected to [[M&T Bank]] Corporation's Board of Directors.{{Cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/36270/000119312517258579/d443507dex991.htm|title=EX-99.1|website=www.sec.gov|access-date=2017-08-25}} ==Statements regarding NSA surveillance== Ledgett pledged increased transparency regarding NSA operations. However, he defended the operations of the NSA and argued in a rare interview with [[Reuters]] that NSA operations are completely legal.{{cite web |last=Zakaria |first=Tabassum |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/12/13/us-usa-security-nsa-idUSBRE9BC0YZ20131213 |title=Exclusive: After 'cataclysmic' Snowden affair, NSA faces winds of change |publisher=Reuters |date=December 13, 2013 |accessdate=2014-02-01}} Ledgett also accused the media of sensationalizing reports about various NSA mass surveillance programs.{{cite web |last=Bercovici |first=Jeff |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jeffbercovici/2014/03/20/at-ted-nsas-deputy-director-says-president-madison-wouldve-been-proud/ |title=At TED, NSA's Deputy Director Says 'President Madison Would've Been Proud' |work=Forbes |date=March 20, 2014 |accessdate=2014-03-22}} In March 2014, Ledgett stated during a [[TED Talk]] that the NSA operates legally. He further argued that President [[James Madison]] would be proud of the way in which Constitutional checks and balances have governed NSA mass surveillance. ==Awards and decorations== {| |- | [[File:NSA Svc 2.JPG|border|60px]] NSA Exceptional Civilian Service Medal |} ==References== ==External links== * {{TED speaker}} ** [http://www.ted.com/talks/richard_ledgett_the_nsa_responds_to_edward_snowden_s_ted_talk "The NSA responds to Edward Snowden’s TED Talk" (TED2014)] {{Deputy DIRNSA}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ledgett, Richard}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Deputy Directors of the National Security Agency]] [[Category:National Security Agency people]] [[Category:Mass surveillance]]

{{Infobox diocese | jurisdiction = Diocese | name = Essen | latin = Dioecesis Essendiensis | local = Bistum Essen | image = Essen 2011 66-2.jpg | image_size = frameless | image_alt = | caption = Essen Cathedral | country = {{flag|Germany}} | metropolitan = [[Essen]], [[North Rhine-Westphalia]] | territory = | province = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Cologne|Cologne]] | coordinates = | area_km2 = 1,877 | population = 2,525,313 | population_as_of = 2013 | catholics = 844,188 | catholics_percent = 33.4 | parishes = | churches = | congregations = | schools = | members = | denomination = [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] | rite = [[Roman Rite]] | established = 1 January 1958 | cathedral = [[Essen Cathedral]] | cocathedral = | patron = [[Our Lady of Good Counsel]] | priests = | pope = {{Incumbent pope}} | bishop = [[Franz-Josef Overbeck]]
Bishop of Essen | metro_archbishop = [[Rainer Maria Woelki]] | coadjutor = | auxiliary_bishops = Ludger Schepers, Franz Vorrath | vicar_general = | emeritus_bishops = [[Felix Genn]] | map = Karte Bistum Essen.png | map_alt = | map_caption = | website = [http://www.bistum-essen.de/ bistum-essen.de] | footnotes = }} The '''Diocese of Essen''' is a bishopric of the [[Catholic Church]] in [[Germany]], founded on 1 January 1958. The Bishop of Essen is seated in [[Essen Cathedral]] (''Essener Dom'' or ''Essener Münster''), once the church of [[Essen Abbey]], and over one thousand years old. The diocese contains about one million Catholics in the heavily urbanized and industrial [[Ruhr Area]].[http://www.wjt2005.de/index.php@id=361&si=1.htm Official website of the XX WYD 2005: Map of Archdioceses and Dioceses / Information / Pilgrimage Sites] ==Bishops== *[[Franz Hengsbach]] (1957–1991) *[[Hubert Luthe]] (1991–2002) *[[Felix Genn]] (2003–2008) *[[Franz-Josef Overbeck]] (since December 20, 2009); he was appointed Bishop of the [[Military Ordinariate of Germany]], while remaining Bishop of Essen, by [[Pope Benedict XVI]] on February 24, 2011 ==See also== *[[Essen]] ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/esse0.htm GCatholic.org] {{Dioceses in Germany|state=collapsed}} {{Authority control}} {{coord|51.4559|N|7.0135|E|source:wikidata|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Essen}} [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses in Germany]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1958]] [[Category:1958 establishments in West Germany]] {{Germany-stub}} {{Europe-RC-diocese-stub}}

{{Infobox diocese |jurisdiction = Diocese |name = San Sebastián |latin = Dioecesis Sancti Sebastiani |local = Diócesis de San Sebastián ''Spanish''
Donostiako Elizbarrutia''Basque'' |image = San Sebastian Buen Pastor.jpg |image_size = 230px |caption = [[San Sebastián Cathedral]] |country = [[Spain]] |metropolitan = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Pamplona y Tudela|Pamplona y Tudela]] |province = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Pamplona y Tudela|Pamplona y Tudela]] |rite = [[Latin Rite]] |established = 2 November 1949 |cathedral = [[Good Shepherd Cathedral of San Sebastián|Cathedral of the Good Shepherd in San Sebastián]] |cocathedral = |area_km2 = 1,977 |population = 684,416 |population_as_of = 2004 |catholics = 621,988 |catholics_percent= 90.9 |pope = {{Incumbent pope}} |bishop = [[José Ignacio Munilla Aguirre]] |metro_archbishop = Francisco Pérez González |coadjutor = |auxiliary_bishops= |map = |website = [http://www.elizagipuzkoa.org/ Website of the Diocese] }} The '''Roman Catholic Diocese of San Sebastián''' ({{lang-la|Sancti Sebastiani}}) is a [[diocese]] located in the city of [[San Sebastián]] in the [[Ecclesiastical province]] of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Pamplona y Tudela|Pamplona y Tudela]] in Spain. ==History== * 2 November 1949: Established as Diocese of San Sebastián ==Special churches== [[Image:Catedral Donostia.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Catedral de El Buen Pastor
(''Cathedral of the Good Shepherd'')|left]] * Cathedral: **[[Good Shepherd Cathedral of San Sebastián|Cathedral of the Good Shepherd]], [[San Sebastián]] * [[Minor basilica]]s: **[[Basilica of Saint Ignatius of Loyola]], [[Azpeitia]] **[[Basilica of Saint Mary of the Chorus]], [[San Sebastián]] ==Leadership== *Jaime Font y Andreu (13 May 1950 – 13 Feb 1963 ) *Lorenzo Bereciartúa y Balerdi (6 Aug 1963 – 23 Oct 1968 ) *Jacinto Argaya Goicoechea (18 Nov 1968 – 16 Feb 1979 ) *[[José María Setién Alberro]] (16 Feb 1979 – 13 Jan 2000 ) *Juan María Uriarte Goiricelaya (13 Jan 2000 – 21 Nov 2009) *José Ignacio Munilla Aguirre (21 Nov 2009 – ) ==See also== *[[Roman Catholicism in Spain]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/zseb1.htm GCatholic.org] [[Wikipedia:SPS|{{sup|[''self-published'']}}]] * [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dsseb.html Catholic Hierarchy] [[Wikipedia:SPS|{{sup|[''self-published'']}}]] * [http://www.elizagipuzkoa.org/ Diocese website] {{Roman Catholic dioceses in Spain}} {{coord|43.3167|N|1.9815|W|source:wikidata-and-enwiki-cat-tree_region:ES|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:San Sebastian}} [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses in Spain]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1949]] [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses and prelatures established in the 20th century]] [[Category:1949 establishments in Spain]] {{Spain-stub}} {{Europe-RC-diocese-stub}}

[[Ladislav Ballek]] | starring = [[Gábor Koncz]] | music = | cinematography = Dodo Simoncic | editing = | distributor = | released = {{Film date|df=yes|1982}} | runtime = 94 minutes | country = Czechoslovakia | language = Slovak | budget = }} '''''The Assistant''''' ({{lang-sk|'''Pomocnik'''}}) is a 1982 Czechoslovakian [[drama film]] directed by [[Zoro Zahon]].{{cite web |url=http://cinema.theiapolis.com/movie-18RT/pomocnik/ |title=Pomocnik |accessdate=26 October 2013 |work=theiapolis}} The film was selected as the Czechoslovakian entry for the [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film|Best Foreign Language Film]] at the [[55th Academy Awards]], but was not accepted as a nominee.Margaret Herrick Library, Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences ==Cast== * [[Gábor Koncz]] as Valent Lancaric * [[Elo Romancik]] as Riecan * [[Ildikó Pécsi]] as Mrs. Riecan * [[Marta Sládecková]] as Eva Riecanová * [[Ivan Mistrík]] as Dobrik * [[Milan Kis]] as Filadelfi * [[József Ropog]] as Torok * [[Hana Talpová]] as Vilma * [[Július Satinský]] as Dr. Bielik ==See also== * [[List of submissions to the 55th Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film]] * [[List of Czechoslovak submissions for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0168135|The Assistant}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Assistant}} [[Category:1982 films]] [[Category:1980s drama films]] [[Category:Slovak films]] [[Category:Slovak-language films]] {{Slovakia-film-stub}} {{1980s-drama-film-stub}}

revision.text:
In March 1972 [[Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Iraq Region|Ba'athist]] [[Iraq]] proposed [[Egypt]] and [[Syria]] to re-establish the '''[[United Arab Republic]]''' which dissolved in 1971. The Iraqi proposal was an immediate reaction to [[Jordan]]'s proposal for a [[King Hussein's federation plan|United Arab Kingdom]] but collided with the already established [[Federation of Arab Republics]] and failed because of Iraqi–Syrian differences.
== Union of Arab Republics == [[File:Union of Arab Republics 1972.png|thumb|The 1972 proposed ''Union of Arab Republics'' (red) was a new version of the 1971 failed ''United Arab Republic'']] The [[King Hussein's federation plan|United Arab Kingdom]] plan was angrily rejected by the [[Palestinians]], the [[Arab League]] and the [[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation|Islamic States]] as well as by [[Israel]]. The Iraqi counter-proposal urged to include the [[Palestine Liberation Organization|PLO]]<ref>Hassan Tawalba: ''The Ba'th and Palestine'', p. 55f. Dar al-Ma'mun, Bagdad 1982</ref> (to fight united for the liberation of Palestine) in an ''Union of Arab Republics'' instead and invited all other "progressive" Arab states to join, too.<ref name="Shibli">[[Shibli al-Aysami]]: ''Einheit, Freiheit, Sozialismus'', p. 99–102. Valle Olona, Varese 1978</ref><ref name="Ron">[[Robin Leonard Bidwell]]: ''Dictionary of Modern Arab History'', p. 429f. Routledge, New York 1998</ref>
[[Libya]], however, should be excluded - at least for the beginning. The Iraqi regime blamed Libya's Revolutionary leader [[Muammar Gaddafi|Gaddafi]] to sponsor Iraqi-Syrian conflicts while Gaddafi condemned the Iraqi regime for its approach to the [[Soviet Union]] and the [[Iraqi Communist Party|Iraqi communists]].<ref name="Shibli" /><ref name="ITN">Reuters 27th March 1972: ''[http://www.itnsource.com/shotlist/RTV/1972/03/27/BGY508150465/?s= Iraqi Delegation Arrives In Cairo For Talks On A Tripartite Federation]'' (with [http://www.itnsource.com/shotlist/RTV/1972/03/27/BGY508150465/?s=#shotListTechnicalInformationAnchor VIDEO clip])</ref>
End of March 1972 Iraqi vice president [[Saddam Hussein]] led a high-ranking delegation to [[Damascus]] and [[Cairo]] in order to promote the proposal. In Syria Saddam Hussein met president [[Hafez al-Assad]] and foreign minister [[Abdul Halim Khaddam]] but Egypt's president [[Anwar Sadat]] had already consulted Gaddafi in Libya. On 26 March Saddam Hussein met Egypt's vice president [[Mahmoud Fawzi]] in Cairo and on 28th he finally met Sadat in [[Alexandria]]. Referring to the already established Egyptian-Libyan-Syrian [[Federation of Arab Republics]] the proposal was rejected.<ref name="Shibli" /><ref name="ITN" /><ref>Record of the Arab World: ''Yearbook of Arab and Israeli Politics'', vol. 1, p. 222. Research and Publishing House, 1972</ref>
However, Syria and Egypt invited Iraq to join the federation instead. According to Khaddam as a first step to unite an Iraqi-Syrian summit should settle the quarrels between the [[Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Syria Region|Syrian Baath-Party]] and the Iraqi Baath-Party. In October 1972 Iraq's president [[Ahmed Hassan al-Bakr]] agreed the Syrian conditions<ref name="Shibli" /> and proposed to create an Iraqi-Syrian union within the federation<ref name="PAN">[[Polish Academy of Sciences|Polska Akademia Nauk]] - Komitet Badań Krajów Azji, Afryki i Ameryki Łacińskiej: ''Studies on the Developing Countries'', No. 1-4 (9-12), p. 180f. Zakład Narodowy im Ossolińskich, Breslau 1989</ref> - as well as Egypt and Libya had already announced to merge bilaterally in a closer union (also called ''United Arab Republic'') within the federation. Although further discussions were not held, in January 1973 the Iraqi regime assured Egypt and Syria its full military and economical support in case of a [[Yom Kippur War|new war against Israel]]. Iraq's offer to create a Joint Military Command was rejected however.<ref name="Shibli" />
